analyzed: tshe 'phos nas ji ltar mthong ste /

original: kye rgyal po chen po /

translated: O Great King,

translated: In whatever place they live, those of the same clan, language, and dress, those not heard of or seen, have all split off from a single ancestor. If now the children, grandchildren, and ancestors associate with each other, what is the limit of association between relatives and children?

original: spad gang la gzung /
analyzed: spad gang la gzung /

translated: If we were to divide people into groups and say, “This person is my ancestor,” and then divide them further, saying, “We are all the children of this person, and we are all his descendants,” and if we were to say that all those whom we now consider our ancestors are the descendants of our first ancestor, then, as the worldly say, after we die, we will not take rebirth in the next life, and our descendants will not be born in the next life either.

original: dang / spun 'grogs na da ltar rus rigs dang / phyogs mi gcig pa dang / dgrar gyur pa kun kyang phyogs gcig nas 'grogs dgos so //
analyzed: dang / spun 'grogs na da ltar rus rigs dang / phyogs mi gcig pa dang / dgrar gyur pa kun kyang phyogs gcig nas 'grogs dgos so //

original: kye rgyal po chen po /

translated: Even in this present life, the visible physical body is in the dark and hidden, and one does not see the other. When the mind that has transmigrated is formless, how can one see the other and associate?

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

translated: Even now, sentient beings with form cannot show their forms to those in different places and different abodes that they cannot see. How can they show their forms after death?

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

analyzed: chung ba rnams pha rol tu'ang dbul rgud nyam chung bar 'gyur ram /

original: rgyal po chen po /

original: 'jig rten pa dag mchi ba ltar ma lags so //

original: byed cing sprul pa ston pa'ang yod do //
analyzed: byed cing sprul pa ston pa'ang yod do //

original: kye rgyal po chen po /

translated: In order to deceive their children, brothers, and so forth, nonhumans cause them to know the signs of death, the earth to tremble, and the stories of the past by means of worldly miracles.🔽

analyzed: rmi lam du 'byung ba yod do // kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: In order to deceive their children, brothers, and so on, nonhuman spirits make them understand the signs of death, the omens of the earth, and the stories of the past, and then, through the power of those spirits, parents and so on see and experience these things in their dreams.

translated: Because of the strong habitual tendencies of seeing and experiencing things together for a long time, children, brothers, and so on appear in dreams.

original: spun zla'am / bran khol lam /
analyzed: spun zla'am / bran khol lam /
translated: For example, a person may see in a dream his or her father, mother, brother, servant, or someone else who has not died.

analyzed: gzhan su'ang rung ba dag dang 'grogs pa dang / longs spyod kyi bde ba'am /

translated: If one dreams of enemies, thieves, fighting, disputes, and so forth, or of any kind of happiness or suffering, then whatever one dreams, one’s father or mother will be like that.

original: spun zla'am / bran khol lam /
analyzed: spun zla'am / bran khol lam /

analyzed: de'i tshe lhas byin de na 'dug pas bcom ldan 'das kyis de skad ces gsungs pa de la yid ma ches nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
translated: At that time, Devadatta, who was present there, did not believe the Blessed One's words. He said to the Blessed One:

original: goo ta ma /
analyzed: goo ta ma /
translated: Gautama,

analyzed: sems can tshe 'phos nas cir 'gyur ba'i dan rtags pha rol na yod pa dang / med pa bka' stsal pa de goo @232a *//
translated: you say that after a sentient being's life ends, there are signs of their existence in the next world, and that there is no such thing.

original: ta mas thog ma su la gsan /
analyzed: ta mas thog ma su la gsan /
translated: Gautama, from whom did you first hear this?

original: dus nam gyi tshe mkhyen par mdzad /
analyzed: dus nam gyi tshe mkhyen par mdzad /
translated: When did you come to know it?

original: gsan pa dang / mkhyen par mdzad pa'i grogs po ni su lags /
analyzed: gsan pa dang / mkhyen par mdzad pa'i grogs po ni su lags /
translated: Who were your companions in hearing and knowing this?🔽When he said this, the Blessed One said:

original: de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
analyzed: de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
translated: Devadatta,

original: lhas byin / ngas ni rang gi lus btang ba la sogs pa dka' ba mang po dag bskal pa grangs med par spyad de sgrib pa thams cad ni sbyangs /
analyzed: lhas byin / ngas ni rang gi lus btang ba la sogs pa dka' ba mang po dag bskal pa grangs med par spyad de sgrib pa thams cad ni sbyangs /
translated: Devadatta, I have practiced for many eons, giving up my body and so forth, and have purified all obscurations.

original: tshogs chen po yang dag par bsags pas thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob ste /
analyzed: tshogs chen po yang dag par bsags pas thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes thob ste /
translated: Through perfectly gathering the great accumulations, I have attained omniscient exalted wisdom.

original: 'das pa'i dus na sngon byung ba dang / da ltar gyi dus na phyogs bcu mtha' yas pa na shes bya gang dag ci yod pa dang / ma 'ongs pa'i dus na 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i shes bya thams cad la mi mkhyen par gyur pa gang yang med de /
analyzed: 'das pa'i dus na sngon byung ba dang / da ltar gyi dus na phyogs bcu mtha' yas pa na shes bya gang dag ci yod pa dang / ma 'ongs pa'i dus na 'byung bar 'gyur ba'i shes bya thams cad la mi mkhyen par gyur pa gang yang med de /
translated: There is nothing whatsoever that I do not know about the objects of knowledge that have occurred in the past, that exist in the ten directions in the present, or that will occur in the future.

original: dper na / dzambu'i gling 'dir nyi ma shar ba de khang dang / rim gyis shar ba ma yin te /
analyzed: dper na / dzambu'i gling 'dir nyi ma shar ba de khang dang / rim gyis shar ba ma yin te /
translated: For example, the sun rising in this world does not rise gradually in the east and gradually in the west.

original: dus gcig tu gsal bar shar ba bzhin du shes bya thams cad skad cig ma gcig la mkhyen pa'i phyir nga ni rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' ba zhes bya'o //
analyzed: dus gcig tu gsal bar shar ba bzhin du shes bya thams cad skad cig ma gcig la mkhyen pa'i phyir nga ni rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' ba zhes bya'o //
translated: It rises simultaneously, and because I know all objects of knowledge in a single instant, I am called “the one who possesses omniscient exalted wisdom.”

analyzed: de skad ces bka' stsal pa la'ang lhas byin yid ma ches nas thams cad mkhyen pa mnga' ba de nyams sad pa'i phyir dzambu'i gling 'di na shing gi rigs tsan dan dang / blag sha dang / seng ldeng la sogs pa shing tha dad pa brgya stong bye ba dag bcad de /
translated: When the Blessed One said this, Devadatta still did not believe it. In order to test whether he had omniscience, Devadatta cut down all the different kinds of trees in this world, such as sandalwood, teak, acacia, and so forth, into a hundred thousand millions of pieces,

original: so sor bsregs nas thal ba'i phur ma byas nas rang gi mi @232b nor bar bya ba'i phyir thal ba la shing gang dang / gang gi ming yi ger btags te /🔽bcom ldan 'das kyi drung du song nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
analyzed: so sor bsregs nas thal ba'i phur ma byas nas rang gi mi @232b nor bar bya ba'i phyir thal ba la shing gang dang / gang gi ming yi ger btags te / bcom ldan 'das kyi drung du song nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
translated: and burned them individually, making piles of ashes. In order to test the Blessed One, he wrote the names of the trees and their ashes on pieces of paper,

analyzed: bcom ldan 'das khyod la thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' na /
translated: and went before the Blessed One. He said to the Blessed One, Blessed One, if you have the wisdom of omniscience,

original: 'di shing gang gi thal ba /
analyzed: 'di shing gang gi thal ba /
translated: then tell me, which of these is the ash of which tree?

original: 'di shing gang gi thal ba lags zhes mthar chags su thal ba'i phur ma thams cad bstan pa las bcom ldan 'das kyis shing gang gi thal ba yin pa ma nor bar 'di ni tsan dan gyi thal ba'o //🔽'di ni blag sha'i thal ba'o //

translated: He asked, Whose ashes are these? and pointed to each of the piles of ashes in turn. The Blessed One correctly identified them all, saying, These are the ashes of sandalwood.🔽These are the ashes of teak.

original: 'di ni seng ldeng gi thal ba'o //
analyzed: 'di ni seng ldeng gi thal ba'o //
translated: These are the ashes of acacia.

original: zhes thal ba'i phur ma thams cad ma nor bar bshad pa las /
analyzed: zhes thal ba'i phur ma thams cad ma nor bar bshad pa las /
translated: In this way he correctly identified all the piles of ashes.

original: lhas byin / bcom ldan 'das la rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' bar yid ches bar gyur te /
analyzed: lhas byin / bcom ldan 'das la rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes mnga' bar yid ches bar gyur te /
translated: Devadatta became convinced that the Blessed One possessed omniscient wisdom.

original: tshe 'phos pa cir 'gyur ba gsungs pa bden par bsams nas /
analyzed: tshe 'phos pa cir 'gyur ba gsungs pa bden par bsams nas /
translated: Thinking that what he had said about what happens after death was true,

original: bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces bstod do //
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces bstod do //
translated: he praised the Blessed One, saying:

original: bcom ldan 'das ni kun mkhyen lags //
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das ni kun mkhyen lags //
translated: The Blessed One is omniscient.

original: shing mang thal ba'i bye brag rnams //
analyzed: shing mang thal ba'i bye brag rnams //
translated: The different ashes of many trees

original: ma gzigs ma gsan nges bar mkhyen //
analyzed: ma gzigs ma gsan nges bar mkhyen //
translated: he has not seen or heard, yet he knows them for certain.

original: tshe 'phos ci 'gyur gsungs pa nges //
analyzed: tshe 'phos ci 'gyur gsungs pa nges //
translated: What happens after death he has said with certainty.

original: zhes bstod nas spobs pa med par gyur to //
analyzed: zhes bstod nas spobs pa med par gyur to //
translated: Having praised him, Devadatta became speechless.

original: de'i tshe sh'akya ming chen de na 'dug pas tshe 'phos pa cir 'gyur ba bka' stsal pa la yi dam ches nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
analyzed: de'i tshe sh'akya ming chen de na 'dug pas tshe 'phos pa cir 'gyur ba bka' stsal pa la yi dam ches nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
translated: At that time, the Śākya Mahānāman was present. He asked the Blessed One what happens to those who have died. He became very faithful and said this to the Blessed One:

original: bcom ldan 'das /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das /
translated: “Blessed One,

original: tshe 'phos pa'i sems can rnams cir 'gyur ba gsungs pa de mngon sum du gzigs sam /
analyzed: tshe 'phos pa'i sems can rnams cir 'gyur ba gsungs pa de mngon sum du gzigs sam /
translated: did you see directly what happens to sentient beings who have died,

original: @233a *// 'on te gzhan zhig la gsan pa lags /
analyzed: @233a *// 'on te gzhan zhig la gsan pa lags /
translated: or did you hear it from someone else?”

original: de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
analyzed: de skad ces gsol pa dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
translated: When he said this, the Blessed One said,

analyzed: ming chen / nga'i sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis mi gzigs pa ni 'jig rten na med de /
translated: “Mahānāman, there is nothing in the world that my buddha eye does not see.

original: skyu ru ra rlon pa lag mthil du bzhag na lag pa'i bye brag thams cad gsal ba de bzhin du dus gsum gyi shes bya la ngas ma gzigs pa ci'ang mi mnga' ste /
analyzed: skyu ru ra rlon pa lag mthil du bzhag na lag pa'i bye brag thams cad gsal ba de bzhin du dus gsum gyi shes bya la ngas ma gzigs pa ci'ang mi mnga' ste /
translated: Just as when a fresh myrobalan fruit is placed in the palm of the hand, all the details of the hand are clear, in the same way, there is nothing at all that I do not see with respect to objects of knowledge in the three times.

original: thos pa la brten pa ni ma yin no //
analyzed: thos pa la brten pa ni ma yin no //
translated: It is not based on hearing.”

original: de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / sh'akya ming chen gyis thams cad gzigs pa de bden rdzun nyams sad pa'i phyir ser skya'i grong khyer chen por song ste /
analyzed: de skad ces bka' stsal pa dang / sh'akya ming chen gyis thams cad gzigs pa de bden rdzun nyams sad pa'i phyir ser skya'i grong khyer chen por song ste /
translated: When the Blessed One had spoken thus, Śākya Mahānāman went to the great city of Kapilavastu in order to test the truth of the Omniscient One.

original: khyim ji snyed yod pa la 'bras kyi phur ma re re blangs te /
analyzed: khyim ji snyed yod pa la 'bras kyi phur ma re re blangs te /
translated: He took a handful of rice from every house.

analyzed: rang gis 'bras kyi phur ma mi gang la blangs pa mi nor bar bya ba'i phyir sh'akya gang la blangs pa'i ming rnams bris te /
translated: In order to avoid taking a handful of rice from the same person twice, he wrote down the names of the Śākyas from whom he had taken rice.

analyzed: 'bras phur ma'i nang du bcug nas 'bras kyi phur ma glang po che'i khal longs pa gcig dang / bcom ldan 'das kyis spyan sngar song ste phyin pa dang / bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to //
translated: He put the names in the handfuls of rice and, with a load of rice on an elephant, went into the presence of the Blessed One. When he arrived, he said to the Blessed One:

original: bcom ldan 'das /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das /
translated: Blessed One,

original: bcom ldan 'das kyis sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis thams cad gzigs na 'bras kyi phur ma 'di dag mi dbye bar sh'akya gang gang gi 'bras gang gang lags pa mkhyen par mdzod cig ces gsol nas /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis thams cad gzigs na 'bras kyi phur ma 'di dag mi dbye bar sh'akya gang gang gi 'bras gang gang lags pa mkhyen par mdzod cig ces gsol nas /
translated: The Blessed One, seeing everything with the eye of a buddha, said, Without separating these heaps of rice, know which rice belongs to which Shakya.

original: glang po che'i khal gyi 'bras kyi phur ma rnams drung du bzhag pa las /
analyzed: glang po che'i khal gyi 'bras kyi phur ma rnams drung du bzhag pa las /
translated: The heaps of rice from the elephant loads were placed in front of him.

analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis 'bras kyi phur ma re re blangs @233b shing 'di sh'akya dga' byed kyi'o //
translated: The Blessed One took up each heap of rice and said, This is Shakya Nandaka's,

original: 'di sh'akya ka ya'i'o //
analyzed: 'di sh'akya ka ya'i'o //
translated: this is Shakya Kaya's,

original: 'di sh'akya 'dod sred kyi'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa 'bras phur ma re re la sh'akya 'di yi'o zhes ming ma nor par rim par rdzogs par gsungs pa las /
analyzed: 'di sh'akya 'dod sred kyi'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa 'bras phur ma re re la sh'akya 'di yi'o zhes ming ma nor par rim par rdzogs par gsungs pa las /
translated: this is Shakya Kâma-tîrtha's, and so on, correctly and in order, naming each heap of rice without error.

original: bcom ldan 'das kyi sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis thams cad gzigs pa la sh'akya ming chen la sogs pa thams cad yid ches te /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyi sangs rgyas kyi spyan gyis thams cad gzigs pa la sh'akya ming chen la sogs pa thams cad yid ches te /
translated: All the Shakyas, including Shakya Mahânâman, believed in the Blessed One's omniscience.

analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis tshe 'phos pa cir 'gyur ba bshad pa ni nges so snyam nas bcom ldan 'das la bstod pa /
translated: The Blessed One has explained what happens to one who has passed away. I am certain of this. He praised the Blessed One, saying,

original: sangs rgyas spyan gyis thams cad gzigs //
analyzed: sangs rgyas spyan gyis thams cad gzigs //
translated: The Buddha sees everything with his eyes.

original: 'jig rten pa ltar rdzun mi mnga'//🔽sh'akya'i grong khyer ji snyed pa'i //
analyzed: 'jig rten pa ltar rdzun mi mnga'// sh'akya'i grong khyer ji snyed pa'i //
translated: He does not lie like worldly people.🔽He knows without error the number of rice grains

original: 'bras kyi phur ma ma nor mkhyen //
analyzed: 'bras kyi phur ma ma nor mkhyen //
translated: in the Shakya city.

original: sems can tshe 'phos pha rol na //
analyzed: sems can tshe 'phos pha rol na //
translated: In the other world, where sentient beings have passed away,

original: ji ltar snang ba 'jig rten rdzun //
analyzed: ji ltar snang ba 'jig rten rdzun //
translated: what appears is a worldly lie.

original: bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa med //
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa med //
translated: The Blessed One has not spoken thus.

original: kun gzigs khyod la phyag 'tshal bstod //
analyzed: kun gzigs khyod la phyag 'tshal bstod //
translated: I pay homage and praise you, all-seeing one.

original: ces bstod nas spobs pa med de mi smra bar 'dug go /
analyzed: ces bstod nas spobs pa med de mi smra bar 'dug go /
translated: Having praised him, he was speechless and remained silent.

original: de nas yab rgyal po chen pos 'di skad ces gsol to //
analyzed: de nas yab rgyal po chen pos 'di skad ces gsol to //
translated: Then the great king, his father, made this request:

original: bcom ldan 'das /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das /
translated: Blessed One,

original: sems can gang dag gis mtshams med pa la sogs pa'i las mi dge ba dag bgyis pas de'i rnam par smin pa mi bzad pa myong bar 'gyur ba dag gis ji ltar bgyis na bde ba thob par 'gyur ba bshad du gsol /
analyzed: sems can gang dag gis mtshams med pa la sogs pa'i las mi dge ba dag bgyis pas de'i rnam par smin pa mi bzad pa myong bar 'gyur ba dag gis ji ltar bgyis na bde ba thob par 'gyur ba bshad du gsol /
translated: Please explain how sentient beings who have committed nonvirtuous actions such as the heinous acts will experience their unbearable ripening and how they can attain happiness.

original: bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa /
translated: The Blessed One replied:

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: “O Great King,

analyzed: sems can gang dag gis mtshams med pa la sogs pa'i las mi dge ba byas pa dag gis sgyu med pa'i @234a *//
translated: sentient beings who have committed nonvirtuous actions such as the heinous acts should, with a mind free of deception,

original: sems dang bas rnam par smin pa la yid ches par byas te /
analyzed: sems dang bas rnam par smin pa la yid ches par byas te /
translated: have confidence in the ripening of karma,

original: sems thag pa nas bshags na 'byang bar 'gyur ro //
analyzed: sems thag pa nas bshags na 'byang bar 'gyur ro //
translated: and if they confess from the depths of their hearts, they will be purified.

analyzed: 'chi ba'i tshe mi dge ba sngar byas pa dag la 'gyod pa bskyed de /
translated: At the time of death, they should generate regret for the nonvirtuous actions they have previously done,

analyzed: sangs rgyas dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad la phyag 'tshal zhing skyabs su gsol na sdig pa 'byang bar 'gyur ro //
translated: and if they pay homage to and take refuge in all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, their negative karma will be purified.”

original: mtho ris su'ang skye bar 'gyur ro; ;tshe phyi ma med pa'i 'du shes bskyed par mi bya'o //
analyzed: mtho ris su'ang skye bar 'gyur ro; ;tshe phyi ma med pa'i 'du shes bskyed par mi bya'o //
translated: One should not generate the notion that there is no next life.

analyzed: skye ba len pa ni dbang phyug dang / 'dod rgyal dang / gyin la sogs bdag gis byed par mi blta'o //
translated: One should not view the taking of rebirth as being done by Īśvara, or by chance, or by nature.

analyzed: 'jig rten pa'i bde ba dang / 'khor ba thams cad la chags par mi bya'o //
translated: One should not be attached to worldly happiness or to the entire cycle of existence.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: “O Great King!

original: 'jig rten 'di nas pha rol tu 'pho ste /
analyzed: 'jig rten 'di nas pha rol tu 'pho ste /
translated: One passes from this world to the next.

translated: When taking rebirth, it is not a permanent transmigration.

original: chad pa 'gags te med pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: chad pa 'gags te med pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: It is not a cessation that ends in nothingness.

original: rgyu med pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: rgyu med pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: It is not without a cause.

original: rgyu med pa las byung ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: rgyu med pa las byung ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: It does not arise without a cause.

original: byed pa pos byas pa'ang ma yin te /
analyzed: byed pa pos byas pa'ang ma yin te /
translated: It is not created by an agent.

original: las dang / nyon mongs pa'i rgyu rkyen tshogs pa las skya bar blta'o //
analyzed: las dang / nyon mongs pa'i rgyu rkyen tshogs pa las skya bar blta'o //
translated: One should view it as arising from the assembly of causes and conditions of karma and afflictions.

original: rgyal po chen pos gsol pa /
analyzed: rgyal po chen pos gsol pa /
translated: The great king said:

analyzed: bcom ldan 'das /
translated: “Blessed One!

analyzed: sems can rnams tshe 'phos nas skye ba len pa de de ltar rtag pa'ang mi 'pho /
translated: When sentient beings die and take rebirth, it is not that they are permanent.

original: chad pa'ang ma lags /🔽rgyu ma  pa'ang ma lags /
analyzed: chad pa'ang ma lags / rgyu ma  pa'ang ma lags /
translated: It is not that they are annihilated.🔽It is not that they are reborn by themselves.

original: byed pa pos yang ma byas /
analyzed: byed pa pos yang ma byas /
translated: It is not that they are reborn by a creator.

analyzed: 'jig rten pha rol tu skye ba'ang 'grub pa de rtogs par dka' na 'di la mthun pa'i dpe mchis sam /
translated: When it is difficult to understand how rebirth in the next world is established, is there a suitable example for this?”

original: bcom ldan 'das kyis @234b bka' stsal pa /
analyzed: bcom ldan 'das kyis @234b bka' stsal pa /
translated: The Blessed One said,

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: “O great king,

original: 'di la mthun pa'i dpe brgyad yod do //
analyzed: 'di la mthun pa'i dpe brgyad yod do //
translated: there are eight suitable examples.

original: bla mas kha ton brjod pa slob mas shes pa'i dpe dang / mar me las mar me 'byung ba'i dpe dang / me long las gzugs brnyan 'byung ba'i dpe dang / rgya las rgya'i 'bur dang / ri mo 'byung ba'i dpe dang / me shel las me 'byung ba'i dpe dang /
analyzed: bla mas kha ton brjod pa slob mas shes pa'i dpe dang / mar me las mar me 'byung ba'i dpe dang / me long las gzugs brnyan 'byung ba'i dpe dang / rgya las rgya'i 'bur dang / ri mo 'byung ba'i dpe dang / me shel las me 'byung ba'i dpe dang /
translated: The example of a student understanding what the teacher recites, the example of a lamp arising from a lamp, the example of a reflection arising from a mirror, the example of a seal and the seal impression, the example of a drawing and the mold, the example of fire arising from a fire glass,

original: sa bon las myu gu 'byung ba'i dpe dang / skyur zhes brjod pas 'gram chu ldang ba'i dpe dang / brag ca'i sgra rnams kyi dpes rtogs par bya ste /
analyzed: sa bon las myu gu 'byung ba'i dpe dang / skyur zhes brjod pas 'gram chu ldang ba'i dpe dang / brag ca'i sgra rnams kyi dpes rtogs par bya ste /
translated: One should understand this by way of the example of the seed and the sprout, the example of the mouth watering when one hears “sour,” and the example of the sound of an echo.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: dpe brgyad po 'di dag gis snga ma snga mas ni phyi ma phyi ma rnams 'byung ba'ang yod pa ni rtag pa 'pho ba ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: dpe brgyad po 'di dag gis snga ma snga mas ni phyi ma phyi ma rnams 'byung ba'ang yod pa ni rtag pa 'pho ba ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
translated: These eight examples show that the former is the cause of the latter, and so they are examples of the non-transfer of permanence.

original: phyi ma phyi mas ni snga ma snga ma rnams las 'byung bas rgyu med pa las 'byung ba ma yin pa'i dpe dang / chad pa 'gag pa ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: phyi ma phyi mas ni snga ma snga ma rnams las 'byung bas rgyu med pa las 'byung ba ma yin pa'i dpe dang / chad pa 'gag pa ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
translated: The latter arises from the former, and so they are examples of the non-arising of causelessness and the non-cessation of nihilism.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: gzhan yang / dpe 'di dag ni rkyen gsum gsum tshogs pa las 'byung ste /
analyzed: gzhan yang / dpe 'di dag ni rkyen gsum gsum tshogs pa las 'byung ste /
translated: Moreover, these examples arise from the assembly of three conditions each.

original: bla ma dang / slob ma de nyid dbang po rnams tshang ba las kha ton 'byung zhing smra shes pa'o //
analyzed: bla ma dang / slob ma de nyid dbang po rnams tshang ba las kha ton 'byung zhing smra shes pa'o //
translated: From the teacher, the student, and the complete sense faculties, there is the arising of recitation and the ability to speak.

original: mar dang / sdong bu dang / snod tshogs pa las mar me 'byung ngo //
analyzed: mar dang / sdong bu dang / snod tshogs pa las mar me 'byung ngo //
translated: From the assembly of butter, the wick, and the vessel, there is the arising of the butter lamp.

original: nam mkha' dang ba dang / gdong dang / me long tshogs pa las gzugs brnyan 'byung ngo //
analyzed: nam mkha' dang ba dang / gdong dang / me long tshogs pa las gzugs brnyan 'byung ngo //
translated: A reflection arises from the assembly of a clear sky, a face, and a mirror.

original: rgya dang / 'jim pa'i gong bu dang / skyes bu lag ba'i rtsol ba rnams tshogs pa las 'bur dang / ri mo 'byung ngo //
analyzed: rgya dang / 'jim pa'i gong bu dang / skyes bu lag ba'i rtsol ba rnams tshogs pa las 'bur dang / ri mo 'byung ngo //
translated: A bas-relief or a painting arises from the assembly of a mold, a lump of clay, and the effort of a person’s hands.

original: she la dang / nyi ma'i 'od dang / rtsva shing tshogs pa las me 'byung ngo //
analyzed: she la dang / nyi ma'i 'od dang / rtsva shing tshogs pa las me 'byung ngo //
translated: Fire arises from the assembly of a magnifying glass, sunlight, and grass or sticks.

original: sa bon dang / sa gzhi dang / rlan pa rnams tshogs pa @235a *//🔽las myu gu byung ngo //
analyzed: sa bon dang / sa gzhi dang / rlan pa rnams tshogs pa @235a *// las myu gu byung ngo //
translated: A sprout arises from the assembly of a seed, the earth, and moisture.

original: tshva dang / tshva chu 'thung myong ba dang / skyur zhes brjod pa tshogs pa las 'gram chu ldang ngo //
analyzed: tshva dang / tshva chu 'thung myong ba dang / skyur zhes brjod pa tshogs pa las 'gram chu ldang ngo //
translated: Saliva arises from the assembly of tasting something sour, saying “sour,” and the memory of tasting something sour.

original: mis brjod pa'i sgra dang / sgra drag po gzhan med pa dang / ri brag rnams tshogs pa las brag ca 'byung ste /
analyzed: mis brjod pa'i sgra dang / sgra drag po gzhan med pa dang / ri brag rnams tshogs pa las brag ca 'byung ste /
translated: An echo arises from the assembly of a sound expressed by a person, the absence of other loud sounds, and mountains or cliffs.

original: de dag ni sems can skye ba ni byed pa pos ma byas te /
analyzed: de dag ni sems can skye ba ni byed pa pos ma byas te /
translated: These are not produced by a creator.

original: las dang / nyon mongs pa'i rgyu rkyen gyis bskyed pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: las dang / nyon mongs pa'i rgyu rkyen gyis bskyed pa'i dpe'o //
translated: They are examples of what is produced by the causes and conditions of karma and mental afflictions.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: gzhan yang bla ma ni tshe 'di'i dpe'o //
analyzed: gzhan yang bla ma ni tshe 'di'i dpe'o //
translated: Moreover, the guru is an example of this life.

original: slob ma ni tshe pha rol gyi dpe'o //
analyzed: slob ma ni tshe pha rol gyi dpe'o //
translated: The disciple is an example of the next life.

original: kha to na ni rnam par shes pa nyid mtshams sbyor ba'i dpe'o //
analyzed: kha to na ni rnam par shes pa nyid mtshams sbyor ba'i dpe'o //
translated: The echo is an example of the linking of consciousness.

original: mar me snga ma ni tshe 'di'i dpe'o //
analyzed: mar me snga ma ni tshe 'di'i dpe'o //
translated: The former lamp is an example of this life.

original: phyi ma ni pha rol gyi dpe'o //
analyzed: phyi ma ni pha rol gyi dpe'o //
translated: The latter is an example of the next life.

original: mar me snga ma las phyi ma byung ba'ang snga ma yod pa ni rtag pa 'pho ba ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: mar me snga ma las phyi ma byung ba'ang snga ma yod pa ni rtag pa 'pho ba ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
translated: The arising of the latter lamp from the former is an example of the existence of the former, which is not a permanent transference.

original: phyi ma de snga ma las byung ba rgyu med pa las ma byung ba'i dpe'o //
analyzed: phyi ma de snga ma las byung ba rgyu med pa las ma byung ba'i dpe'o //
translated: The arising of the latter from the former is an example of not arising from a noncause.

original: me long ni tshe 'di yod pa'i sga nas phyi ma'ang yod la /
analyzed: me long ni tshe 'di yod pa'i sga nas phyi ma'ang yod la /
translated: The mirror is an example of the existence of the next life from the existence of this life,

original: dngos po'ang mi 'pho zhing pha rol yang yod nges pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: dngos po'ang mi 'pho zhing pha rol yang yod nges pa'i dpe'o //
translated: and of the existence of the next life, without the transference of the entity.

original: rgya ni 'dir las ci spyad pa mthun par pha rol tu'ang skye ba len pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: rgya ni 'dir las ci spyad pa mthun par pha rol tu'ang skye ba len pa'i dpe'o //
translated: The seal is an example of taking birth in the next life in accordance with whatever karma is performed here.

original: me shel ni 'gro ba ris mi 'dra ba nas mi 'dra bar skye ba'i dpe'o //
analyzed: me shel ni 'gro ba ris mi 'dra ba nas mi 'dra bar skye ba'i dpe'o //
translated: The fire crystal is an example of birth in different realms from different realms.

original: sa bon ni 'gags nas med par mi 'gyur ba'i dpe'o //
analyzed: sa bon ni 'gags nas med par mi 'gyur ba'i dpe'o //
translated: The seed is an example of not becoming nonexistent after cessation.

original: skyur ni myong ba'i las kyis skye ba len pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: skyur ni myong ba'i las kyis skye ba len pa'i dpe'o //
translated: The sour taste is an example of the karma of experience taking rebirth.

original: sgra ni rgyu rkyen tshogs nas gnod pa'i rkyen gzhan med na skye ba len te /
analyzed: sgra ni rgyu rkyen tshogs nas gnod pa'i rkyen gzhan med na skye ba len te /
translated: The sound is an example of the collection of causes and conditions taking rebirth when there are no other conditions of harm.

original: gcig pa dang / tha dad pa ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
analyzed: gcig pa dang / tha dad pa ma yin pa'i dpe'o //
translated: It is an example of neither being the same nor being different.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: dpe brgyad bo 'di tshang bar ma smos te /
analyzed: dpe brgyad bo 'di tshang bar ma smos te /
translated: These eight examples are not complete.

original: 'ga' @235b zhig bstan na dbang phyug dang / 'dod rgyal dang / gyi na dang / rgyu med par smra ba dag gis dge sbyong goo ta ma'i dpe 'di dag kha ton gyi dpes ni 'di'i phung po dang / rnam par shes pa gnyis ma bral bar pha rol tu rnam par shes pa 'pho bar 'gyur zhes smra ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
analyzed: 'ga' @235b zhig bstan na dbang phyug dang / 'dod rgyal dang / gyi na dang / rgyu med par smra ba dag gis dge sbyong goo ta ma'i dpe 'di dag kha ton gyi dpes ni 'di'i phung po dang / rnam par shes pa gnyis ma bral bar pha rol tu rnam par shes pa 'pho bar 'gyur zhes smra ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
translated: If some are taught, the proponents of Īśvara, chance, and causelessness will say, “These examples of the ascetic Gautama are like the example of recitation. By this example, the two, the aggregates and consciousness, are not separated. It is said that consciousness transfers to the other side.” The remaining examples are taught to refute that.

original: mar me'i dpes ni 'di dang / pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod do zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
analyzed: mar me'i dpes ni 'di dang / pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod do zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
translated: By the example of the lamp, it is said that both this and the other side have the aggregates at the same time. The remaining examples are taught to refute that.

original: me long gi dpes ni 'dra ba'i dpe yin pas grum po las grum por skye /🔽dkar po las dkar por skye'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //🔽rgya'i dpes ni lha 'phos pa lhar skye /🔽mi 'phos pa mir skye ba la sogs pa nges pa'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //🔽me shel gyi dpes ni mi 'dra ba'i dpe yin pas dge bas ngan song dang / mi dge bas mtho ris 'grub bo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //🔽sa bon gyi dpes ni shes pa gcig las mang por 'phel lo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
analyzed: me long gi dpes ni 'dra ba'i dpe yin pas grum po las grum por skye / dkar po las dkar por skye'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to // rgya'i dpes ni lha 'phos pa lhar skye / mi 'phos pa mir skye ba la sogs pa nges pa'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to // me shel gyi dpes ni mi 'dra ba'i dpe yin pas dge bas ngan song dang / mi dge bas mtho ris 'grub bo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to // sa bon gyi dpes ni shes pa gcig las mang por 'phel lo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
translated: The mirror example is a homogeneous example, because it is said that a leper is born from a leper and a white person is born from a white person.

original: ngan song gi lo rgyus yod pa dag mi dge ba ma byas kyang ngan song du skye'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i @236a *//
analyzed: ngan song gi lo rgyus yod pa dag mi dge ba ma byas kyang ngan song du skye'o zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i @236a *//
translated: Some people say, There are stories of people being born in the lower realms even though they did not commit nonvirtuous actions, and they deny the law of cause and effect.

original: phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
analyzed: phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
translated: The remaining examples are taught in order to refute those who say that there are stories of people being born in the lower realms even though they did not commit nonvirtuous actions.

original: sgra'i dpes ni byed pa po'i dpe yin pas rgyu rkyen las ma byung ngo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
analyzed: sgra'i dpes ni byed pa po'i dpe yin pas rgyu rkyen las ma byung ngo zhes zer ba dag dgag pa'i phyir dpe lhag ma rnams bstan to //
translated: The remaining examples are taught in order to refute those who say that the self is not produced from causes and conditions, since the example of the creator is the example of the self.

original: de'i phyir dpe brgyad bstan to //
analyzed: de'i phyir dpe brgyad bstan to //
translated: Therefore, eight examples are taught.

original: kye rgyal po chen po /
analyzed: kye rgyal po chen po /
translated: O Great King!

original: tshe zhig ste pha rol tu skye ba med de /
analyzed: tshe zhig ste pha rol tu skye ba med de /
translated: There is no rebirth in the next life after this life ends.

original: chad pa dang / 'gag pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: chad pa dang / 'gag pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: It is not annihilated, nor does it cease.

original: tshe 'di dngos po rtag pa ma nyams par pha rol tu 'pho ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: tshe 'di dngos po rtag pa ma nyams par pha rol tu 'pho ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: This life does not transfer to the next life as a permanent entity without changing.

original: tshe 'di la ma bsten par pha rol tu skye ba len pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: tshe 'di la ma bsten par pha rol tu skye ba len pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: Rebirth is not taken in the next life without depending on this life.

original: bdag gis skye ba 'di blang ngo zhes bsams pas kyang skye ba mi len to //
analyzed: bdag gis skye ba 'di blang ngo zhes bsams pas kyang skye ba mi len to //
translated: Rebirth is not taken by thinking, “I will take this rebirth.”

original: bdag gis dbang phyug chen po la sogs pa la brten te mtho ris su skye bar bya'o snyam pas kyang ma yin no //
analyzed: bdag gis dbang phyug chen po la sogs pa la brten te mtho ris su skye bar bya'o snyam pas kyang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one thinks, “By relying on Maheśvara and so on, I will be born in the higher realms.”

original: bdag mtho ris dang / ngan song gar 'dod par skye bar bya'o snyam pas kyang ma yin no; ;ci'ang ma byas te rgyu rkyen la brten mi dgos par skye'o snyam bas kyang ma yin no //
analyzed: bdag mtho ris dang / ngan song gar 'dod par skye bar bya'o snyam pas kyang ma yin no; ;ci'ang ma byas te rgyu rkyen la brten mi dgos par skye'o snyam bas kyang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one thinks, “I will be born in the higher realms or the lower realms wherever I wish.” Nor is it that one thinks, “I will be born without doing anything at all, without needing to rely on causes and conditions.”

original: phung po 'di zhig ste shi nas ci'ang med do zhes smra ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: phung po 'di zhig ste shi nas ci'ang med do zhes smra ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one says, “This aggregate is destroyed at death, and after death there is nothing at all.”

original: 'dir tshe 'phos nas pha rol na gshin gyi khams su mu chags su mchis pas 'di na ci spyod pa byed de skye ba mi len zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: 'dir tshe 'phos nas pha rol na gshin gyi khams su mu chags su mchis pas 'di na ci spyod pa byed de skye ba mi len zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one says, “After death, one goes to the other side, to the realm of the dead, and there one experiences the results of one’s actions here, but one does not take rebirth.”

original: tshe 'di'i rnam par shes pa ma 'gags par rnam par shes pas skye ba len zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: tshe 'di'i rnam par shes pa ma 'gags par rnam par shes pas skye ba len zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one says, “The consciousness of this life takes rebirth without ceasing.”

original: 'di dang / pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod ces zer ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: 'di dang / pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod ces zer ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one says, “The aggregates exist simultaneously in this life and the next.”

original: grum po las grum por skye /
analyzed: grum po las grum por skye /
translated: Nor is it that one says, “A leper is born from a leper.”

original: dkar po las @236b dkar por skye zhes bya ba la sogs pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: dkar po las @236b dkar por skye zhes bya ba la sogs pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that from a virtuous action a virtuous effect arises, and so on.

original: lha tshe 'phos pa'ang lhar skye'o //
analyzed: lha tshe 'phos pa'ang lhar skye'o //
translated: Nor is it that when a god dies, he is reborn as a god,

original: mi tshe 'phos pa'ang mir skye'o zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: mi tshe 'phos pa'ang mir skye'o zhes zer ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: or that when a human dies, he is reborn as a human.

original: dge bas ngan song dang / mi dge bas mtho ris su 'grub ces zer ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: dge bas ngan song dang / mi dge bas mtho ris su 'grub ces zer ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that through virtue one goes to the lower realms, or that through non-virtue one goes to the higher realms.

original: shes pa gcig las mang po 'phel ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: shes pa gcig las mang po 'phel ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that from a single consciousness many arise.

original: dge ba ma byas kyang lhar skye ba dang / mi dge ba ma byas kyang ngan song du skye ba'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: dge ba ma byas kyang lhar skye ba dang / mi dge ba ma byas kyang ngan song du skye ba'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is it that one is reborn as a god without having performed virtuous actions, or that one is reborn in the lower realms without having performed non-virtuous actions.

original: skye ba ni byed pas byas pa'ang ma yin no //
analyzed: skye ba ni byed pas byas pa'ang ma yin no //
translated: Nor is rebirth created by a creator.

original: de dag ci'i phyir ma yin zhe na /
analyzed: de dag ci'i phyir ma yin zhe na /
translated: Why is it not so?

original: kha ton gyi dpe la gang dag gis rnam par shes pa 'di ma 'gas par pha rol tu skye ba len no zhes zer ba'i skyon bsal ba'i phyir sa bon gyi dpe bstan te /
analyzed: kha ton gyi dpe la gang dag gis rnam par shes pa 'di ma 'gas par pha rol tu skye ba len no zhes zer ba'i skyon bsal ba'i phyir sa bon gyi dpe bstan te /
translated: To dispel the fault of those who say that this consciousness, without being destroyed, takes rebirth in the next life, using the example of recitation, the example of the seed is taught.

original: sa bon de ma rul bar myu gu skye na ni bdag tu smra ba dag bden na sa bon de rul nas snga ma las gyur te mi 'dra bar gyur pa las myu gu skye'o //
analyzed: sa bon de ma rul bar myu gu skye na ni bdag tu smra ba dag bden na sa bon de rul nas snga ma las gyur te mi 'dra bar gyur pa las myu gu skye'o //
translated: If a sprout were to arise from a seed that has not decomposed, then the proponents of a self would be correct. But the seed decomposes and changes into something different from what it was before, and then the sprout arises.

original: mar me'i dpe la gang gis mar me gcig las gcig bar na gnyis ka yod pas 'di dang pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod do zhes zer ba'i skyon bsal ba'i phyir sgra'i dpe bstan te /
analyzed: mar me'i dpe la gang gis mar me gcig las gcig bar na gnyis ka yod pas 'di dang pha rol gnyis kar phung po dus gcig yod do zhes zer ba'i skyon bsal ba'i phyir sgra'i dpe bstan te /
translated: In the example of the lamp, someone might say that since both the previous and subsequent moments of the flame exist when one flame arises from another, the aggregates exist in both this life and the next simultaneously. To dispel this error, the example of sound is taught.

original: brag ca ni mis ma brjod par sgra mi grag ste /
analyzed: brag ca ni mis ma brjod par sgra mi grag ste /
translated: An echo does not sound without a person speaking.

original: dus gcig tu mi 'byung bas phung po'ang dus gcig tu mi 'byung ngo //
analyzed: dus gcig tu mi 'byung bas phung po'ang dus gcig tu mi 'byung ngo //
translated: Since it does not occur simultaneously, the aggregates do not occur simultaneously.

original: me long gi dpe la 'dra ba'i phyir grum po las grum por skye ba dag dgag pa'i phyir me shel gyi dpe bstan te /
analyzed: me long gi dpe la 'dra ba'i phyir grum po las grum por skye ba dag dgag pa'i phyir me shel gyi dpe bstan te /
translated: In the example of the mirror, the example of the magnifying glass is taught in order to refute the arising of something similar from something similar, as in the case of a mole arising from a mole.

original: me shel las de dang mi 'dra ba'i me 'byung ba'i phyir ro //
analyzed: me shel las de dang mi 'dra ba'i me 'byung ba'i phyir ro //
translated: Because fire arises from a magnifying glass, which is not similar to a mole.

original: rgya'i dpe ni lha tshe 'phos pa ltar skye /
analyzed: rgya'i dpe ni lha tshe 'phos pa ltar skye /
translated: The example of the mold is like the rebirth of a god.

original: mi @237a *// tshe 'phos pa mir skye'o zhes zer ba bsal ba'i phyir kha ton gyi dpe bstan te /
analyzed: mi @237a *// tshe 'phos pa mir skye'o zhes zer ba bsal ba'i phyir kha ton gyi dpe bstan te /
translated: The example of recitation is taught in order to eliminate the claim that a person who has transmigrated is born as a human.

analyzed: rgya'i ri mo ci 'dra ba de las 'jim pa'i gong bu la'ang ri mo gzhan mi 'byung ba'i phyir ro //

translated: Those who have experienced the story of the sour fruits will be born as gods in all their lives without having to perform any virtuous actions.🔽

original: me long la bzhin ci 'dra ba snang ba bzhin du dge ba dang / mi dge ba'i 'bras bu 'dra ba bsnol nas mi 'dra bar sbyor ba 'gal ba'i phyir ro //

original: sgra'i dpe la ni byed pa pos byas pa ma yin te /
analyzed: sgra'i dpe la ni byed pa pos byas pa ma yin te /
translated: In the example of sound, it is said that it is not created by an agent.🔽Just as an echo does not occur without a person shouting, sentient beings are not born without an agent.
